messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:17): 65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c: there is one benefit to it being a free-form editable piece of text -- the code to do that already exists.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:17): and is deployed
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:17): and has an active spam-fighting community
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:17): (hober)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (11:17): sure, and the HTML4.01 spec is already written and been published as REC
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (11:18): there's lots of things we could choose not to do because something exists
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (11:18): not saying this case is of nearly equal importance
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:18): sure, i'm just disagreeing with "there's really no benefit to the wiki page being a free-form editable piece of text"
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:18): i'm happy to have something better
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:19): but unless someone steps up and writes the code for it, that's theoretical.
2c39bccd623947fa6224ea57d2a727de (11:19): and maintains it
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:19): indeed
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:20): (i think it would be better to have a wiki on the w3c's site than the whatwg site, btw)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:20): (wikipedia or wikibooks would be even better if they were up for it)
2c39bccd623947fa6224ea57d2a727de (11:21): maybe they can create wikistry
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:21): hehe
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (11:22): that would probably deliver more of a promise of long-term continuity and be politically more congenial to some
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (11:23): still strikes me personally as too unstructured
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (11:23): but I have already talked way too much about a topic I profess to care little about
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:23): heh

b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:29): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: We can leave the innerHTML-on-foreign-content stuff to "v2" of course, but I would expect it to be in demand given that many js libraries rely heavily on innerHTML
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (11:30): and will presumably be used in more situations with mixed namespace content once it is supported in text/html
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:38): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: yeah, agreed
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:44): ok bed time
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:44): nn
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:03): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: I think I drink about a gallon of green tea before lunch
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:03): and two gallons after
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:04): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: I normally drink a lot of green tea, but today has been black
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:04): I can't drink that much black tea
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:05): it gives me ick mouth after a point
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:05): and if I drank that much coffee, i'm pretty sure I'd have to be hospitalized
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:05): ewww, coffee
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:06): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: btw, I get the impression you have lost interest, but I will soon be unleashing on you an enhancement patch for anolis
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:06): and if nothing else it should provide you with some laughing-at-my-expense entertainment value
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:07): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: I've said as much
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:07): well, at this will olet you get a glimpse of my, um, approach to coding

a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:07): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: I'll probably dump the code I have for Anolis 2 somewhere public soon and just let anyone who wants xdoc support to get it to work
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:07): OK, well, I'll have something you can add to the dump
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:08): and possibly something you can contribute to the Daily WTF and get an award or something
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:09): hugs a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:09): Self-confidence!
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:09): a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554: your code is nice and refined, like a jeweler working on a watch movement
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:09): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: ‚Ä¶
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:09): mine is like a guy bashing a TV on the side to make it show a better picture
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:09): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: Anolis was the first thing I ever wrote in Python. It's horrific.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:10): you ain't seen nothing yet
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:10): I've written cleaner Perl than the Python of Anolis.
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:10): Oh, I've seen plenty of bad code.
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:10): I will say that this exercise of trying to add a new feature to anolis has given me a whole new appreciation for the etree API
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:11): which is not saying much, because my appreciation for that API was previously zero
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:12): and I would not have ever tried to use it unless it seemed like the quickest and bash-the-TV-iest way to get done what I wanted to get done
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:12): but now that I've messed around with it a bit, I have to say it has its own appeal
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:12): kind of like Bizarro Superman
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:12): It has some fairly horrible flaws, though
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:13): true that
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:13): The etree api as implemented in lxml is pretty good
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:13): Could do with a .textContent
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:13): it doesn't have one of its own?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:14): .text_content() ?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:14): or is that part of lxml?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:14): ah yeah
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:14): Umm, maybe it does now
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:14): You can't do anything better than etree.to_string(node, type="unicode")
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:14): oh, lxml.html does
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:14): Odd
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (12:14): "".join(node.xpath(".//text()"))
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:14): b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea: Slow, comparitively
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:15): (Anolis used to do that)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:15): i recall this thing:
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:16): etree.tostring(foo, method='text')
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:16): return etree.tostring(Element, encoding=unicode, method='text', with_fail=False) is what Anolis does now
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:16): I think I used that etree.tostring(foo, method='text') for about 3 seconds, before I found some right-er way of doing it
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:17): anolislib.utils.textContent(foo)
a11aabeeceeae6b8cb5d12ea06b56554 (12:17): :P
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:17): anyway, it's a nice respite for the pain of working with native W3C DOM directly
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:18): s/respite for/respite from/
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:19): the entire W3C DOM should be enshrined in Daily WTF in a place of high honor
2c39bccd623947fa6224ea57d2a727de (12:19): hmm, adding more features to XMLHttpRequest Level 2 while change requests are ongoing for Level 1
2c39bccd623947fa6224ea57d2a727de (12:19): this is gonna be fun
2c39bccd623947fa6224ea57d2a727de (12:19): maybe I should wait
2c39bccd623947fa6224ea57d2a727de (12:21): hmm, I think that leaves CSS values
2c39bccd623947fa6224ea57d2a727de (12:21): I don't really like working on that

a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:21): W3C DOM Daily WTF award: The guy who couldn't conceive that path/selector node selection is way better the constant redundant tree walking all the freaking time
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:21): what is CSS values?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:21): a political document?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:21): that should be a lot of fun to work on
2c39bccd623947fa6224ea57d2a727de (12:22): its like ele.style.values.width.px++
2c39bccd623947fa6224ea57d2a727de (12:22): it's even
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:23): even?
2c39bccd623947fa6224ea57d2a727de (12:23): but I guess I should at least take a stab at it, working on XHR2 can wait a little longer, and I'm not sure if I want to start on Web DOM Core just yet
2c39bccd623947fa6224ea57d2a727de (12:23): it's rather than its
2c39bccd623947fa6224ea57d2a727de (12:24): correcting a typo
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:24): Web Notifications fun will be ramping up pretty soon
2c39bccd623947fa6224ea57d2a727de (12:24): I think Web DOM Core might be my next challenge in cleaning up legacy stuff
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (12:24): yeah, do that
2c39bccd623947fa6224ea57d2a727de (12:24): ah yeah, that will be my challenge at adding cruft to the platform that creates future legacy problems ;p
